>Haven't some experiments been done where they added the time component
>to the model and then were able to do some very sophisticated learning
>with very few neurons, compared to the simpler activation wave method?

I have wondered, and I'm not sure I ever mentioned, whether a 
time-component can be used to simplify the multiplexing/routing question 
for real brains (as we have gone into in some detail in the "Symmetry, 
concepts and data buses in the brain" thread, amongst others).

What I am thinking about is the presence of periodic waves on EEG traces 
(you know, alpha-waves, beta-waves...) and it occurs to me that the phase 
of a repeating wave provides a way to separate different data in a single 
network.  e.g. what I mean is, suppose the wave is something like this:

http://tinypic.com/a9quzp.gif

Inagine a whole system is clocking with that wave.  We can isolate 
different parts of the wave as different (temporal) regions (e.g. in the 
diagram I cut it into "high", "falling", "low" and "rising" sections) and 
then if we fed the system a different part of the input data during each 
phase, we can have four different "concepts" present in one network...

On a short time scale, the four sets of data are present in the network at 
different times, but viewed over a longer time-frame (one or more whole 
cycles) they are all present at the same time, just in different phases.

Thus we have a mechanism for bringing multiple data sets into a single 
network without having to provide a multiplexer between the data-store and 
the processing network.  Instead, all we need is four "trigger lines", each 
going high during a different phase of the cycle.  And an instruction to 
each data store telling it which of those lines means to send its 
contents.  The output from the stores can then all be mixed into a single 
channel, as only one store will ever be transmitting at a time.

Comparisons between different concepts can be achieved simply by having 
some delays in the net, so that data from a previous phase is still around 
when a later one arrives.

Prioritizing different concepts can be achieved by giving the different 
phases different priorities and switching the concepts between them based 
on processing in the net.

A search can be performed by keeping the current best concept in one phase 
and iterating other concepts through the other phases...

Just some beer-mat theorising...

         Ian

((The word "concept" used metaphorically throughout this document.))

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
